subject: Re: [junit] Test genes, test infected rates, and test-resistant managers
msgSnippet: ... As a closet academic, there s an additional point to be made between these last two steps.  The schools that many look to for definition of the standard
messageBody:
On 1/25/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> 1. Practitioners generate a great idea.
> 2. Practitioners test the idea: some like it, some don't.
> 3. If enough like it, some start teaching it.
> 4. If enough teach it, some /schools/ start teaching it.
> 5. If enough schools teach it, it becomes part of the standard curriculum.

As a closet academic, there's an additional point to be made between
these last two steps. The schools that many look to for definition of
the standard curriculum have classes taught by academics. Many
software academics are crack developers with excellent ideas about
producing quality code quickly. Some have spent more of their life
getting paid to think about software than produce it. Most have a
certain blindspot when it comes to TDD and unit testing in general,
though, I believe:

In research, it can be hard to say in advance what your code is
supposed to be doing.

There are ways to incrementally well-tested units that contribute to
an overall whole that is still somewhat amorphous, but it does
require, to a certain extent, changing both how you think about
research and software, and it's taken me a while to figure out even as
much as I have. For example, it's often worth keeping a well-tested,
but low-performing algorithm around at least until you can build a
second algorithm that can do as well. All that said, the number of
long-standing research projects with even slightly comprehensive unit
tests is much less than a T1 person would hope.

David Saff
